BUSINESS\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'GENERAL\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Sunbeam Corporation (collectively with its subsidiaries, the "Company" or\n', b'"Sunbeam") is a leading designer, manufacturer and marketer of branded consumer\n', b"products. The Company's primary business is the manufacture, marketing and\n", b'distribution of durable household consumer products through mass market and\n', b'other distributors in the United States and internationally. The Company also\n', b'sells its products to commercial end users such as hotels and other\n', b'institutions (the "Away From Home" category of the business).\n', b'\n', b'\n', b"     The Company's product categories are: (1) Appliances (mixers, blenders,\n", b'food steamers, bread makers, rice cookers, coffee makers, toasters, irons and\n', b'garment steamers) (2) Health at Home (vaporizers, humidifiers, air cleaners,\n', b'water filters, massagers, hot and cold packs, blood pressure monitors and\n', b'scales) (3) Personal Care and Comfort (shower massagers, hair clippers and\n', b'trimmers, electric warming blankets and throws) (4) Outdoor Cooking (electric,\n', b'gas and charcoal grills and grill accessories) and (5) Away From Home (clippers\n', b'and related products for the professional beauty, barber and veterinarian trade\n', b'and sales of products to commercial and institutional channels). The\n', b'International Group is responsible for sales (primarily of small appliances,\n', b'personal care, grills and comfort products, professional clippers and related\n', b'products) in all countries other than the United States.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Sunbeam products enjoy a long-standing reputation for quality, and a\n', b"majority of the Company's sales are from products which hold the number one or\n", b'two market share in their respective product categories.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The Company was organized in 1989 (as Sunbeam-Oster Company, Inc.) and in\n', b'September 1990, Sunbeam acquired the assets and assumed certain liabilities,\n', b'through a reorganization, of Allegheny International, Inc. (the "Predecessor"),\n', b'an entity operating as a debtor-in-possession under Chapter 11 of the United\n', b'States Bankruptcy Code since 1988. In August 1992, the Company completed a\n', b'public offering of 20,000,000 shares of its common stock. In May 1995, the\n', b'Company changed its name from Sunbeam-Oster Company, Inc. to Sunbeam\n', b'Corporation.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'RESTRUCTURING AND GROWTH PLAN\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     In the Fall of 1996, under newly elected Chairman, Albert J. Dunlap, the\n', b'Company announced a major restructuring and growth plan. The restructuring\n', b'portion of the plan was completed during 1997, resulting in a significant\n', b'reduction in employees, facilities and costs, all of which is anticipated to\n', b'generate approximately $225 million in annual savings for the Company. As a\n', b'part of the restructuring plan, the Company divested its non-core businesses\n', b'and assets, including furniture, time and temperature, decorative bedding, gas\n', b'heaters and logs, Counselor/registered trademark/ and Borg/registered\n', b"trademark/ scale businesses and the Company's Biddeford, Maine textile mill.\n", b'\n', b'\n', b"     The Company's restructuring plan included the closure of 18 factories, 43\n", b'warehouses and 5 headquarters, resulting in the consolidation of all corporate\n', b'offices into a single headquarters office located in Delray Beach, Florida and\n', b'an operations center at its Hattiesburg manufacturing and distribution\n', b'facility. The number of manufacturing facilities has been reduced from\n', b'twenty-six to eight (four in the US and four international). See "Properties"\n', b'below.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The Company has also consolidated all purchasing functions, substantially\n', b'reduced the number of stock keeping units maintained by the Company and\n', b'outsourced certain administrative, manufacturing and distribution activities.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The Company has developed a comprehensive three year growth plan for its\n', b"core businesses. Sunbeam's goal is for revenues to double, reaching $2 billion\n", b'by 1999, with operating margins improving\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'                                       1\n', b'<PAGE>\n', b'\n', b'to 20% of sales. This revenue growth is anticipated to be derived, in large\n', b'part, by the development of new innovative products and the globalization of the\n', b'Company. Domestically, the goal is to introduce at least 30 new products each\n', b'year; during 1997, the Company introduced 35 new domestic products and 54 new\n', b'international products. In its international business, the Company has a goal to\n', b'triple international sales to $600 million by 1999. During 1997 the Company\n', b'entered into 25 new international distribution/license agreements. The Company\n', b'has also identified new channels of distribution as additional sales growth\n', b'opportunities, including commercial organizations and "direct to the consumer"\n', b'channels such as catalogs, the Internet and Sunbeam/registered trademark/\n', b'factory outlet stores. These growth plans do not reflect the impact of the\n', b"Company's pending acquisitions of The Coleman Company, Inc., Signature Brands\n", b'USA, Inc. and First Alert, Inc. See "PENDING ACQUISITIONS".\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Both international expansion and new product introductions will be\n', b'supported by a significant investment in a major new advertising program that is\n', b'geared to continually strengthening the Sunbeam/registered trademark/,\n', b'Oster/registered trademark/, Grillmaster/registered trademark/ and other brands\n', b'in the marketplace.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'PENDING ACQUISITIONS\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     On March 2, 1998, the Company announced that it had entered into three\n', b'separate agreements to acquire The Coleman Company, Inc., Signature Brands USA,\n', b'Inc. and First Alert, Inc. The three transactions are subject to customary\n', b'conditions, including the receipt of required regulatory approvals, and are\n', b'expected to close early this spring.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The Coleman Company, Inc. ("Coleman"), with 1997 revenues of approximately\n', b"$1.1 billion, is the world's leading manufacturer and marketer of outdoor\n", b'recreational products. It manufactures and distributes widely diversified\n', b'product lines for camping, leisure time and hardware markets, under the\n', b'Coleman/registered trademark/, Powermate/registered trademark/, Camping\n', b'Gaz/registered trademark/ and Eastpak/registered trademark/ brand names. The\n', b'Coleman transaction is valued at approximately $2.0 billion, consisting of\n', b'approximately $811 million in Company common stock, approximately $260 million\n', b'in cash and the assumption of debt.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Signature Brands USA, Inc. ("Signature Brands"), with 1997 revenues of\n', b'approximately $279 million, is a leading manufacturer of a comprehensive line of\n', b'consumer and professional products, including coffee makers marketed under the\n', b'Mr. Coffee/registered trademark/ brand name and consumer health products\n', b'marketed under the Health-o-Meter/registered trademark/, Counselor/registered\n', b'trademark/ and Borg/registered trademark/ brand names. The Signature Brands\n', b'transaction is valued at approximately $250 million, consisting of cash and the\n', b'assumption of debt.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     First Alert, Inc. ("First Alert"), with revenues of approximately $187\n', b'million, is the worldwide leader in residential safety equipment including smoke\n', b'and carbon monoxide detectors marketed under the First Alert/registered\n', b'trademark/ brand name. The First Alert transaction is valued at approximately\n', b'$175 million, consisting of cash and the assumption of debt.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     In connection with the three transactions, the Company intends to seek to\n', b'negotiate a new bank credit facility and to issue other debt securities. See\n', b'"Item 7 - Management\'s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and\n', b'Results of Operation - Liquidity and Capital Resources."\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'PRODUCTS\n', b'\n', b'\n', b"     The Company's core product categories are as follows:\n", b'\n', b'\n', b'APPLIANCES\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Small kitchen appliances including Mixmaster/registered trademark/ stand\n', b'mixers, hand mixers, Osterizer/registered trademark/ blenders, food processors,\n', b'rice cookers, food steamers, toasters, can openers, coffee makers, bread\n', b'makers, waffle makers, ice cream makers, frying pans, deep fryers and culinary\n', b'accessories, are sold primarily under the Sunbeam/registered trademark/ and\n', b'Oster/registered trademark/ brand names. The Company holds the number one or\n', b'two market positions in blenders, mixers, and bread makers. The Appliance\n', b'category also encompasses garment care appliances consisting of irons and\n', b"steamers. Sales of appliances accounted for approximately 32% of the Company's\n", b'domestic net sales in 1997.\n', b'\n', b'                                       2\n', b'<PAGE>\n', b'\n', b'HEALTH AT HOME\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The Company markets its home health products under the Sunbeam/registered\n', b'trademark/ name and the trademark Health at Home/registered trademark/. These\n', b'products include heating pads, bath scales, blood pressure and other health-\n', b'monitoring instruments, massagers, vaporizers, humidifiers and dental care\n', b'products. This product category also includes the recently introduced\n', b'AllergySmart/trademark/ air detector and air cleaner and the\n', b'FreshSource/trademark/ power water filter. Sales of health care products\n', b"accounted for approximately 10% of the Company's domestic net sales in 1997.\n", b'\n', b'\n', b'PERSONAL CARE AND COMFORT\n', b'\n', b'\n', b"     The Company's personal care and comfort products include a broad line of\n", b'electric blankets, comforters and Cuddle-Up/registered trademark/ heated\n', b'throws, shower massagers, and hair clippers and trimmers for animals and humans\n', b'which are sold through retail channels. The Company holds the number one market\n', b'position in electric blankets, heated throws and retail hair clippers. Sales of\n', b'personal care and comfort products accounted for approximately 18% of the\n', b"Company's domestic net sales in 1997.\n", b'\n', b'\n', b'OUTDOOR COOKING\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Sunbeam is a leading supplier of outdoor barbecue grills. Sunbeam has the\n', b'leading market share position in the gas grill industry. Barbecue grills\n', b'consist of propane, natural gas, electric and charcoal models sold primarily\n', b'under the Sunbeam/registered trademark/ and Grillmaster/registered trademark/\n', b'brand names. Sales of outdoor cooking products accounted for approximately 34%\n', b"of the Company's domestic net sales in 1997.\n", b'\n', b'\n', b'AWAY FROM HOME\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The Company markets a line of professional barber, beauty and animal\n', b'equipment, including electric and battery clippers, replacement blades and\n', b'other grooming accessories sold to both\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'                                       3\n', b'<PAGE>\n', b'\n', b'conventional retailers and through professional distributors. In addition, the\n', b'Company is expanding the marketing of its appliances, scales and personal care\n', b'and comfort products to institutional and commercial channels. Sales of away\n', b'from home products accounted for approximately 6% of the\n', b"Company's domestic net sales in 1997.\n", b'\n', b'\n', b'INTERNATIONAL\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The Company markets a variety of products (primarily small kitchen\n', b'appliances, personal care and comfort products, grills, professional clippers\n', b'and related products ) outside the U.S. While the Company sells many of the\n', b'same products domestically and internationally, it also sells products designed\n', b'specifically to appeal to foreign markets. The Company, through its foreign\n', b'subsidiaries, has manufacturing facilities in Mexico and Venezuela, and sales\n', b"offices in Canada, the United Kingdom, Hong Kong and Australia. The Company's\n", b"international products are sourced from the Company's United States, Mexican or\n", b'Venezuelan manufacturing operations or from vendors primarily located in Asia.\n', b"International sales accounted for approximately 21% of the Company's total net\n", b'sales in 1997.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b"     To date, the Company's activities outside the United States have been\n", b'primarily focused in Mexico, Latin America and Canada. The Company enjoys a\n', b'strong market position in a number of product categories in Latin America. The\n', b'Oster/registered trademark/ brand has the leading market share in small\n', b'appliances in a number of Latin American countries.\n', b'\n', b"     The Company's pending acquisitions of Coleman, Signature Brands and First\n", b'Alert are anticipated to provide new opportunities for international expansion\n', b'of the Company\'s activities. See "Pending Acquisitions".\n', b'\n', b'COMPETITIVE STRENGTHS\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Worldwide, Sunbeam competes in markets with a number of well-established\n', b'United States and foreign companies on the basis of various strengths,\n', b'depending on the country, product category and distribution channels. The\n', b'Company believes that it is well-positioned to pursue continued growth as a\n', b'result of several competitive strengths, which include the following:\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     DISTRIBUTION NETWORK. The Company has one of the premier mass merchant\n', b'distribution networks serving large national retailers in the United States.\n', b'The Company also has a strong network of well-established distributors and\n', b'service organizations in Latin America. The Company supports its customers\n', b'needs with strong warehousing and distribution capabilities, a broad,\n', b'high-quality product portfolio, electronic data interchange ("EDI") and\n', b'just-in-time product delivery capabilities. The Company markets its products\n', b'through virtually every category of retailer including mass merchandisers,\n', b'catalog showrooms, warehouse clubs, department stores, catalogues,\n', b'Company-owned outlet stores, television shopping channels, hardware stores,\n', b'home improvement centers, drug and grocery stores, and pet supply retailers, as\n', b'well as independent distributors and military post exchange outlets.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     STRONG POSITION IN CONSOLIDATING RETAIL ENVIRONMENT. The consolidation\n', b'trend in the retail industry has resulted in the emergence and global expansion\n', b'of large mass merchandisers that demand financially strong, efficient suppliers\n', b'which offer a broad range of innovative, quality products with the ability to\n', b'make timely shipments in large volumes and provide strong customer, promotional\n', b'and merchandising support. The Company has benefited from this trend and\n', b'believes it has the opportunity to further expand distribution with a number of\n', b'retailers and increase its penetration of existing\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'                                       4\n', b'<PAGE>\n', b'\n', b'accounts. In 1997, the Company sold products to virtually all of the top 100\n', b'U.S. retailers, including Wal-Mart, Price Costco, Kmart, Target Stores, Home\n', b"Depot, Sears, Roebuck & Co., Service Merchandise, Menards, Lowe's and J.C.\n", b'Penney.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     BRAND NAME RECOGNITION. The Sunbeam/registered trademark/ and\n', b'Oster/registered trademark/ brands have been household names for generations.\n', b'The Company believes that these brands, along with its other well-known\n', b'secondary names such as Mixmaster/registered trademark/ and\n', b'Osterizer/registered trademark/ draw customers into retail stores specifically\n', b'to purchase products bearing these brand names. During the past year, the\n', b'Company has spent over $56 million for advertising and sales promotion to\n', b'support brand recognition.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     MARKET LEADERSHIP. The majority of Sunbeam sales are from products in\n', b'which the Company holds the number one or two market share position. The\n', b'Company believes that this combination of leading brand-name products and\n', b'breadth of product offerings makes Sunbeam an attractive vendor to retailers\n', b'who are consolidating their suppliers.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'CUSTOMERS\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The rapid growth of large mass merchandisers and warehouse clubs and\n', b'changes in consumer shopping patterns have contributed to a significant\n', b'consolidation of the U.S. retail industry and the formation of dominant\n', b'multi-category retailers. Sunbeam has positioned itself to respond to the\n', b'challenges of this changing retail environment by pursuing strategic\n', b'relationships with large, high-volume merchandisers. The Company markets its\n', b'products through virtually every category of retailer including mass\n', b'merchandisers, catalog showrooms, warehouse clubs, department stores, hardware\n', b'stores, catalogues, television shopping channels, home centers, drug and\n', b'grocery stores, and pet supply retailers, as well as independent distributors\n', b"and the military post exchange services. The Company's largest customer,\n", b'Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., accounted for approximately 21% of sales in 1997.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Retailers are pursuing a number of strategies in their competition to\n', b'deliver the highest-quality, lowest-cost brand name products. A growing trend\n', b'among retailers is to purchase on a "just-in-time" basis in order to reduce\n', b'inventory costs and increase returns on investment. This trend has required\n', b'increased working capital investments for manufacturers and requires\n', b'manufacturers to more closely monitor consumer buying patterns as retailers\n', b'shorten their lead times for orders. Currently, most Sunbeam products sold to\n', b"U.S. retailers are manufactured at the Company's own facilities in North\n", b'America. However, one of the Company\'s goals for 1998 is to "source"\n', b'approximately fifty percent (50%) of parts and/or products from others,\n', b'including suppliers in Asia, in order to reduce capital investment in plants\n', b'while growing sales volume and to improve operating margins. The Company\n', b'intends to continue to support its retail partners\' "just-in-time" inventory\n', b'strategies through investments in, among other things, improved forecasting\n', b'systems, more responsive manufacturing and distribution capabilities and\n', b'electronic communications. Currently, Sunbeam has approximately 90% of its U.S.\n', b'customer sales on electronic data interchange (EDI) systems.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The amount of backlog orders at any point in time is not a significant\n', b"factor in the Company's business.\n", b'\n', b'\n', b'PATENTS AND TRADEMARKS\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Sunbeam believes that an integral part of its strength is its ability to\n', b'capitalize on the Sunbeam/registered trademark/ and Oster/registered trademark/\n', b'trademarks which are registered in the United States and in numerous foreign\n', b'countries. Widely recognized throughout North America, South and Central\n', b'America and Europe, these registered trademarks, along with\n', b'Osterizer/registered trademark/, Mixmaster/registered trademark/, Toast\n', b'Logic/registered trademark/, Steammaster/registered trademark/,\n', b'Oskar/registered trademark/, Grillmaster/registered trademark/ and Blanket\n', b'with a Brain/registered trademark/ brands are important to the success of the\n', b"Company's products. Other important trademarks within Sunbeam include Oster\n", b'Designer/registered trademark/ line, Cuddle-Up/registered trademark/ and\n', b'A5/registered trademark/.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Sunbeam holds numerous patents covering a wide variety of products, the\n', b'loss of any one of which would not have a material adverse effect on the\n', b"Company's business taken as a whole.\n", b'\n', b'\n', b'                                       5\n', b'<PAGE>\n', b'\n', b'EMPLOYEES\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The Company currently has approximately 3,300 full-time domestic employees\n', b"and 4,200 international employees. None of the Company's domestic full-time\n", b'workforce has union representation. Sunbeam has had no material labor-related\n', b'work stoppages and, in the opinion of management, relations with its employees\n', b'are generally good.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'SEASONALITY\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     On a consolidated basis, Sunbeam sales do not exhibit substantial\n', b'seasonality. However, sales of outdoor cooking products are strongest in the\n', b'first half of the year, while sales of appliances and personal care and comfort\n', b'products are strongest in the second half of the year. In addition, sales of a\n', b"number of the Company's products, including warming blankets, vaporizers,\n", b'humidifiers and grills may be impacted by unseasonable weather conditions.\n', b'During 1997, the Company initiated early buy programs for highly seasonal\n', b'products such as grills and warming blankets in order to more levelize\n', b'production and distribution activities.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'RAW MATERIALS\n', b'\n', b'\n', b"     The raw materials used in the manufacture of the Company's products are\n", b'available from numerous suppliers in quantities sufficient to meet normal\n', b"requirements. The Company's primary raw materials include aluminum, steel,\n", b'resin, copper, and corrugated cardboard for cartons.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'ENVIRONMENTAL MATTERS\n', b'\n', b'\n', b"     The Company's operations, like those of comparable businesses, are subject\n", b'to certain federal, state, local and foreign environmental laws and regulations\n', b'in addition to laws and regulations regarding labeling and packaging of\n', b'products and the sale of products containing certain environmentally sensitive\n', b'materials ("Environmental Laws"). The Company believes it is in substantial\n', b'compliance with all Environmental Laws which are applicable to its operations.\n', b'Compliance with Environmental Laws involves certain continuing costs; however,\n', b'such costs of ongoing compliance have not resulted, and are not anticipated to\n', b"result, in a material increase in the Company's capital expenditures or to have\n", b"a material adverse effect on the Company's results of operations, financial\n", b'condition or competitive position.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     In addition to ongoing environmental compliance at its operations, the\n', b'Company also is actively engaged in certain environmental remediation\n', b'activities relating primarily to divested operations. As of December 31, 1997,\n', b'the Company had been identified by the United States Environmental Protection\n', b'Agency ("EPA") or a state environmental agency as a potentially responsible\n', b'party ("PRP") in connection with seven (7) sites subject to the federal\n', b'Superfund law and two (2) sites subject to state Superfund laws comparable to\n', b'the federal law (collectively the "Environmental Sites"), exclusive of sites at\n', b'which the Company has been designated (or expects to be designated) as a de\n', b'minimis (less than 1%) participant.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The Superfund Act, and related state environmental remediation laws,\n', b'generally authorize governmental authorities to remediate a Superfund site and\n', b'to assess the costs against the PRPs or to order the PRPs to remediate the site\n', b'at their expense. Liability under the Superfund Law is joint and several and is\n', b'imposed on a strict basis, without regard to degree of negligence or\n', b'culpability. As a result, the Company recognizes its responsibility to\n', b'determine whether other PRPs at a Superfund site are financially capable of\n', b'paying their respective shares of the ultimate cost of remediation of the site.\n', b'Whenever the Company has determined that a particular PRP is not financially\n', b'responsible, it has assumed for purposes of establishing reserve amounts that\n', b'such PRP will not pay its respective share of the costs of remediation. To\n', b"minimize the Company's potential liability with respect to the Environmental\n", b'Sites, the Company has actively participated in steering committees and other\n', b'groups of PRPs established with respect to such sites. The Company currently is\n', b'engaged in active remediation activities at nine (9) sites, four (4) of which\n', b'are among the Environmental Sites referred to above, and five (5) of which have\n', b'not been designated as Superfund sites under federal or state law.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'                                       6\n', b'<PAGE>\n', b'\n', b'     In addition, the Company is engaged in environmental remediation\n', b'activities at a site located in Newburgh Heights, Ohio, where a subsidiary\n', b'formerly conducted operations. The Company has been actively cooperating with\n', b'the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission and state regulatory\n', b'authorities in developing and implementing a plan for remediation of this site;\n', b'which remediation is anticipated to be substantially completed in 1998.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b"     The Company's costs for environmental remediation activities have not had\n", b"a material adverse effect on the Company's results of operations, financial\n", b'condition or competitive position. The Company has established reserves to\n', b'cover the anticipated probable costs of remediation, based upon periodic\n', b'reviews of all sites for which the Company has, or may have, remediation\n', b'responsibility. As of December 28, 1997, the amount of such reserves was\n', b"approximately four percent (4%) of the Company's total liabilities as set forth\n", b'in the consolidated financial statements. Such environmental reserves do not\n', b'anticipate any offsets for potential insurance recoveries from certain of the\n', b"Company's liability insurance carriers which the Company continues to pursue.\n", b'\n', b'\n', b'     Due to uncertainty over the remedial measures to be adopted at some sites,\n', b'the possibility of changes in the Environmental Laws, and the fact that joint\n', b'and several liability with the right of contribution is possible at federal and\n', b"state Superfund sites, the Company's ultimate future liability with respect to\n", b'sites at which remediation has not been completed may vary from the amounts\n', b'reserved at fiscal year end 1997. However, the Company believes, based on\n', b'existing information, that the costs of completing the environmental\n', b'remediation of all sites for which the Company has a remediation responsibility\n', b'have been adequately reserved and that the ultimate resolution of these matters\n', b"will not have a material adverse effect upon the Company's financial condition.\n", b' \n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     In December 1996, the Company reached a negotiated settlement with the EPA\n', b'with regard to a notice of violation concerning the construction and operation\n', b"of two paint lines at the Company's Neosho, MO facility prior to obtaining the\n", b'necessary permits for construction and operation. The negotiated settlement\n', b'amount of $829,825 recognizes the benefits of a "supplemental environmental\n', b'project" which consisted of the Company\'s installation of nominal emission\n', b'powder coating lines to replace solvent paint lines. In October 1997, the\n', b'Company executed a Consent Decree documenting the settlement and is awaiting\n', b"the EPA's execution of the Consent Decree; the Company anticipates formal\n", b'resolution of this matter by the second quarter of 1998.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The Company is not a party to any other administrative or judicial\n', b'proceeding to which a governmental authority is a party and which involves\n', b'potential monetary sanctions, exclusive of interest and costs, of $100,000 or\n', b'more.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'CAUTIONARY STATEMENTS\n', b'\n', b'\n', b"     Certain of the information contained herein (including Management's\n", b'Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations)\n', b'contains "forward-looking" information, as that term is defined in the Private\n', b'Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, as the same may be amended (herein the\n', b'"Act") and in releases made by the Securities and Exchange Commission ("SEC")\n', b'from time to time. In\n", b'addition, the Company expects to benefit from various operating synergies\n', b'arising from these acquisitions. If the Company fails to maintain its current\n', b'operations in the manner anticipated or fails to obtain the expected operating\n', b"synergies, such failures could negatively effect the Company's financial and/or\n", b'operating performance, which effect could be material.\n', b'\n', b'     /bullet/ The Company expects to significantly increase the amount of its\n', b'outstanding indebtedness and to enter into financing arrangements which may\n', b'contain various restrictive covenants, in order to finance the acquisitions of\n', b'Coleman, Signature Brands and First Alert. The continuing cost of\n', b"servicing such debt could negatively effect the Company's future operations,\n", b'which effect could be material.\n', b'\n', b"     /bullet/ The Company's performance should be expected to be affected by\n", b'the strength of the retail economy, primarily in the United States, but also in\n', b'Canada, Latin America and Asia. Weakness in\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'                                       7\n', b'<PAGE>\n', b'\n', b'consumer confidence and retail outlets (including the financial weakness or\n', b'bankruptcy of retail outlets, especially mass merchants) should be expected to\n', b"adversely impact the Company's future financial results. In addition, the\n", b'extended credit terms provided by the Company in connection with its "early buy"\n', b"program increase the Company's risk of collection of accounts receivable.\n", b'\n', b'     /bullet/ The Company operates in a highly competitive environment with\n', b'numerous competitors which are financially strong and capable of competing\n', b'effectively with the Company in the marketplace. Such competitors may take\n', b"actions to meet the Company's new product introductions and other initiatives.\n", b'Some competitors may be willing to accept lower margins and to reduce prices to\n', b'compete with the Company. As a result, the Company could fail to achieve\n', b'anticipated sales increases, to realize anticipated price increases, or\n', b'otherwise fail to meet its anticipated goals. Any of such circumstances would\n', b'likely have an adverse effect on future financial performance, which effect\n', b'could be material.\n', b'\n', b'     /bullet/ The Company currently manufactures approximately 70% of its\n', b"products. One of the Company's goals for 1998 is to source approximately 50% of\n", b"the Company's parts and/or products from third parties. The Company's ability\n", b'to realize sales and operating profits at anticipated levels is dependent upon\n', b'its ability to timely manufacture, source and deliver products which may be\n', b'sold for a profit. Labor difficulties, delays in delivery or pricing of raw\n', b'materials and/or sourced products, scheduling and transportation difficulties,\n', b'management dislocations and delays in development and manufacture of new\n', b'products can negatively affect operating profits. Although the Company will use\n', b'its best efforts to select suppliers for sourced product which are reliable and\n', b"dependable, the Company's planned increase in the percentage of sourced\n", b"products will decrease the Company's immediate control of product and, if such\n", b'suppliers fail to deliver products as anticipated, could have an adverse effect\n', b'on future financial performance, which effect could be material.\n', b'\n', b"     /bullet/ As a consumer goods distributor, the Company's results of\n", b'operations can be negatively impacted by product liability lawsuits, product\n', b'recall actions and/or by higher than anticipated rates of warranty returns or\n', b'other returns of goods.\n', b'\n', b'     /bullet/ The Company expects to substantially increase the amount of\n', b'business conducted by it outside North America. If the Company fails to achieve\n', b'anticipated market penetration in areas of the world into which the Company\n', b'currently expects to expand its sales, such event is likely to have an adverse\n', b"effect on the Company's future financial performance, which effect could be\n", b"material. Expansion of the Company's sales in foreign markets depends upon many\n", b'factors, including the states of economies in foreign countries, the strength\n', b'of consumer demand in those countries for products which the Company sells (or\n', b'expects to sell in those markets), the strength of competition from other\n', b'global consumer products companies and other factors which may negatively\n', b"affect the Company's anticipated performance in those markets. Although the\n", b'recent financial instability in Asia has not currently had any material impact\n', b'on the Company, if such conditions continue and/or worsen, they could\n', b"negatively impact the Company's ability to achieve anticipated sales growth in\n", b"such countries, the effect of which could be material to the Company's future\n", b'financial performance.\n', b'\n', b'     /bullet/ The Company currently manufactures some products and has sales in\n', b'such economies as those of Mexico and Venezuela, both of which economies have\n', b'been unstable or hyperinflationary in recent years. The economies of other\n', b"foreign countries important to the Company's expansion plans, including other\n", b'countries in Latin America and Asia, could suffer similar instability in the\n', b'future. Such factors as currency devaluations, new tariffs, changes in monetary\n', b'policies, inflation, governmental instability and similar matters could\n', b"negatively affect the Company's anticipated performance in foreign markets.\n", b'Although the Company plans to take advantage of recent economic and currency\n', b"fluctuations in certain Asian countries by increasing the Company's purchases\n", b'of products from such countries at lower prices, there is no guarantee that\n', b'such purchasing advantage will be fulfilled or will fully overcome any lost\n', b'sales opportunities in those same countries. As a result, the economic\n', b'conditions discussed above or any of these circumstances could have an adverse\n', b'effect on future financial performance, which effect could be material.\n', b'\n', b'     /bullet/ A significant portion of the cost of goods manufactured by the\n', b'Company in North America is the cost of raw materials and/or components. The\n', b'Company has implemented changes in its purchasing\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'                                       8\n', b'<PAGE>\n', b'\n', b'function which have enabled the Company to purchase materials more efficiently\n', b"and economically than it has in the past. The future success of the Company's\n", b"purchasing initiatives may be affected by many factors beyond the Company's\n", b'control, such as commodity pricing generally and higher prices for the specific\n', b'materials required by the Company. Although there are numerous suppliers\n', b'available for the materials and components sourced by the Company, any\n', b'unanticipated change in suppliers could be disruptive and costly to the\n', b"Company. In addition, the Company's future initiatives to reduce the cost of\n", b'materials simply may not achieve savings in amounts comparable to those\n', b'previously obtained by the Company. A significant failure by the Company to\n', b'maintain material costs as anticipated would likely have an adverse effect on\n', b'anticipated future financial performance, which effect could be material.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     /bullet/ The Company anticipates realizing price increases from time to\n', b'time for certain of its products. The Company operates in a highly competitive\n', b'industry, and its ability to realize price increases may be limited due to\n', b'competitive pressures. If there is a material failure to realize anticipated\n', b'price increases, margins likely will be lower than anticipated by the Company,\n', b'and this will likely have an adverse effect on future financial performance,\n', b'which effect could be material.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     /bullet/ The Company anticipates that it will be able to more rapidly\n', b'develop and introduce a substantial number of new and innovative products in\n', b'the future. However, the Company may prove unable to meet its more aggressive\n', b'schedules for future product development. Failure to develop and manufacture\n', b'new products in the amounts and with the quality anticipated or a failure to\n', b'reduce the cycle time for new product introductions would likely have an\n', b'adverse effect on future financial performance, which effect could be material.\n', b' \n', b'\n', b'\n', b"     /bullet/ Sales of certain of the Company's products can be negatively\n", b'impacted by unseasonable weather conditions during different seasons and\n', b"quarters of the year. For instance, the Company's sales of warming blankets\n", b'were negatively impacted in the fourth quarter of 1997 by moderate temperatures\n', b'in the northern states. The Company has attempted to levelize production,\n', b'marketing and other activities related to seasonal products by implementing an\n', b'"early buy" program; such a program shifts certain of the weather related risks\n', b'of negative sales impact for such seasonal products to later months of the\n', b'season and, as result, could have a negative impact on future financial\n', b'performance.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     /bullet/ The Company has entered into various arrangements with third\n', b'parties for the provision of back-office administrative services previously\n', b'provided with internal resources, including provision of all necessary computer\n', b'systems. Failure of any of these third party service providers to perform in\n', b'accordance with their respective agreements with the Company could result in\n', b"disruptions of the Company's normal business operations with a consequent\n", b'impact on sales, collections, cash flow and/or profitability.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b"     /bullet/ The Company's profitability may be negatively impacted by\n", b'underabsorption of manufacturing costs resulting from underutilization of\n', b"manufacturing capacity if the Company's sales growth is less than anticipated.\n", b'\n', b'\n', b'                                       9\n', b'<PAGE>\n', b'\n', b'ITEM 2. MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS\n", b'        OF OPERATION\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'YEAR ENDED DECEMBER 28, 1997 COMPARED TO THE YEAR ENDED DECEMBER 29, 1996\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     In November 1996, the Company initiated a major restructuring and growth\n', b'plan designed to substantially reduce its cost structure and grow the business\n', b'in order to restore higher levels of profitability for the Company. By July\n', b'1997, the Company completed the major phases of the restructuring plan. The\n', b'$225.0 million of annualized cost savings anticipated from the restructuring\n', b'results primarily from the consolidation of administrative functions within the\n', b'Company, the rationalization of manufacturing and warehouse facilities\n', b'(including a reduction in the number of production facilities from 26 to 8 and\n', b'warehouses from 61 to 18), the elimination of over 6,000 positions (including\n', b'3,300 from the divestiture of non-core businesses described below and\n', b"approximately 2,800 other positions), the centralization of the Company's\n", b'procurement function and re-negotiation of supply contracts resulting in\n', b'procurement savings for raw materials, components and sourced finished products\n', b"and the reduction of the Company's product offerings and stock keeping units\n", b'("SKU\'s"). The restructuring and growth plan also included a redefinition of the\n', b"Company's core product categories and the elimination of those businesses and\n", b"product lines that did not fit the core categories. Sunbeam's core product\n", b'categories are Appliances, Health at Home, Personal Care and Comfort, Outdoor\n', b'Cooking and Away From Home. Product categories and businesses determined to be\n', b"non-core were divested in 1997, including the Company's furniture business and\n", b'its time and temperature, decorative bedding and Counselor/registered trademark/\n', b'and Borg/registered trademark/ scale product lines. In addition, the Company\n', b'sold its textile mill in Biddeford, Maine in 1997.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Net sales from continuing operations for 1997 were $1,168.2 million, an\n', b'increase of $183.9 million or 18.7% over 1996. Net sales on a normalized basis,\n', b'after excluding divested product lines which are not classified as discontinued\n', b'operations (time and temperature products, decorative bedding and\n', b'Counselor/registered trademark/ and Borg/registered trademark/ branded scales),\n', b'increased 22.4% during the year.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Global sales, on a normalized basis, increased during 1997 in all five of\n', b"the Company's product categories primarily from new product introductions,\n", b"improved distribution (particularly with the Company's top ten customers),\n", b'international geographic expansion and improved price realization for certain\n', b'products. Global sales growth on a normalized basis exceeded 25% in the\n', b'Appliance, Outdoor Cooking and Away From Home categories with sales increases\n', b'of 26.8%, 27.2% and 28.6%, respectively. Sales in the Health at Home category\n', b'increased 10.7% on a normalized basis and sales in the Personal Care and\n', b'Comfort category increased 3.4% during 1997.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b"     The Company's Appliance category sales increases were driven by new\n", b'products, such as re-designed blenders and mixers, coffeemakers, irons, deep\n', b'fryers and toasters, and by increased distribution with large national mass\n', b'retailers. Sales of Outdoor Cooking products increased in 1997 after three\n', b'straight years of declines as a result of increased merchandising and\n', b'advertising programs, new distribution and the introduction of an entirely new\n', b'line of grills and accessories for the 1998 season that began to ship in the\n', b'fourth quarter of 1997 under a new "early buy" marketing program that included\n', b'among other things, extended credit terms with due dates in the second quarter\n', b'of 1998. The Company sold approximately $50.0 million of Outdoor Cooking\n', b'Products under this program in the fourth quarter of 1997. The early buy program\n', b'for Outdoor Cooking products is designed to improve customer service levels and\n', b'production efficiencies with more level seasonal production and distribution\n', b'activities that have historically peaked in the first half of each year and to\n', b'drive additional retail sell-through of Outdoor Cooking products by reducing the\n', b'likelihood of retail stock-outs during the important first and second quarter\n', b'1998 selling season.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Sales of Personal Care and Comfort products were up over 30% through\n', b'September 1997, but suffered during the fourth quarter as a result of lower\n', b'than expected retail sell through of electric blankets in key northern markets\n', b'in late 1997 coupled with the inability to service demand for king and queen\n', b'sized blankets due to shortages of blanket shells. The Company anticipates\n', b'shifting to a more\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'                                       14\n', b'<PAGE>\n', b'\n', b'level production for blankets in 1998 in order to more adequately service the\n', b'seasonal demand for bedding products. Health at Home category sales increased\n', b'as a result of new products and improved distribution in the drug channels.\n', b'Away from Home sales increased in 1997 as a result of new products, including\n', b'cordless clippers and titanium blades coupled with increased distribution of\n', b"commercially rated appliances. Also contributing to the Company's sales growth\n", b'in 1997 were its new retail outlet stores, of which 22 were open by the end of\n', b'1997.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     International sales, which represented 21% of total revenues in 1997, grew\n', b'31.2% during the year. This sales growth was driven primarily by 54 new 220\n', b'volt product introductions and the execution of 25 new international\n', b'distribution and license agreements. Revenue growth of approximately 34% was\n', b"achieved both in Mexico and by the Company's Latin American export sales\n", b'organization, and sales in Venezuela and Canada increased approximately 23%\n', b'each. European sales fell slightly in 1997, however the Company expects that\n', b'expanded electric blanket and clipper sales along with the help of additional\n', b'new distribution agreements will benefit European sales in 1998.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The gross margin percentage for 1997 increased 19.8 percentage points to\n', b'28.3%. This increase reflects the results of many cost savings and margin\n', b"enhancement initiatives undertaken as part of the Company's restructuring plan\n", b'coupled with the incremental margin attributable to new products and higher\n', b"revenues associated with the Company's growth plan. The Company initiated a\n", b'manufacturing refinement program in the second quarter of 1997 targeted at\n', b'aggressively improving factory productivity at all of its remaining operations,\n', b'including the Neosho, Missouri Outdoor Cooking Products facility which suffered\n', b'from poor productivity and operating inefficiencies during the 1997 grill\n', b'season. The benefits of the refinement program began to favorably impact\n', b'factory productivity in several factories during the third quarter of 1997. The\n', b'refinement of the Neosho facility, which was completed prior to the initiation\n', b'of production for the 1998 grill season in the fourth quarter, included a\n', b'revised plant layout to improve material flow, increased usage of common parts\n', b'in the manufacturing process and modifications to the paint system to increase\n', b'capacity and throughput.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Operating earnings for 1997 were $199.4 million, an increase of $195.0\n', b'million over 1996, excluding the impact of the 1996 special charge. As a\n', b'percentage of sales, the operating margin of 17.1% increased 16.6 percentage\n', b"points above last year's operating margin, excluding 1996 special charges. The\n", b'operating margin improvements for 1997 were the result of the improved gross\n', b'margin discussed above and lower selling, general and administrative ("SG&A")\n', b'costs in 1997 associated with the consolidation of six divisional and regional\n', b'headquarters into one corporate headquarters and one administrative operations\n', b'center, reduced staffing levels, the outsourcing of certain administrative and\n', b'distribution functions, a reduction in the number of warehouses, and Company\n', b'wide cost control initiatives. In addition, SG&A during 1996 included\n', b'incremental compensation costs associated with restricted stock awards and\n', b'other costs related to the employment of a new senior management team, higher\n', b'than normal expenditures for market research, packaging and other initiatives\n', b"related to the launch of the Company's growth plan, and higher bad debt\n", b"expenses associated with certain of the Company's customers. The cost reduction\n", b'initiatives and one time items in 1996 coupled with increased sales in 1997\n', b'resulted in SG&A decreasing as a percentage of sales from 17.4% in 1996\n', b'(excluding the impact of special charges) to 11.2% for 1997.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Interest expense decreased from $13.6 million in 1996 to $11.4 million in\n', b'1997 primarily as a result of lower average borrowing levels in 1997 due to\n', b'improved cash flows.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The effective income tax of 35% for 1997 and 1996 for earnings (loss) from\n', b'continuing operations was lower than the statutory federal and state rates as a\n', b'result of lower foreign taxes from the utilization of foreign tax credits and\n', b'loss carryforwards and lower state income taxes as a result of certain state\n', b'income tax credits.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b"     The Company's diluted earnings per share from continuing operations was\n", b'$1.41 per share versus a loss per share from continuing operations in 1996 of\n', b"$2.37. The Company's share base utilized in the diluted earnings per share\n", b'calculation increased approximately 6% during 1997 as a result of an increase\n', b'in the number of shares of common stock and common stock equivalents\n', b'outstanding due to the exercise of stock options and a higher market value of\n', b"the Company's common stock in 1997.\n", b'\n', b'\n', b'                                       15\n', b'<PAGE>\n', b'\n', b"     The Company's discontinued furniture operations, which were sold in March\n", b'1997, had revenues of $51.6 million in the first quarter of 1997 prior to the\n', b'sale and break-even earnings. In 1996, the discontinued furniture operations\n', b'had net income of $.8 million on revenues of $227.5 million and an estimated\n', b'loss on disposal of the business of $32.4 million, net of applicable income tax\n', b"benefits. The sale of the Company's furniture business assets (primarily\n", b'inventory, property, plant and equipment) was completed in March 1997.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The Company received $69 million in cash and retained accounts receivable\n', b'related to the furniture business of approximately $50.0 million as of the\n', b'closing date. The final purchase price for the furniture business was subject\n', b'to a post-closing adjustment based on the terms of the Asset Purchase Agreement\n', b'and in the first quarter of 1997, after completion of the sale, the Company\n', b'recorded an additional loss on disposal of $13.7 million, net of income tax\n', b'benefits. See discussion of Restructuring, Impairment and Other Costs in Note 8\n', b"and Discontinued Operations and Assets Held For Sale in Note 9 to the Company's\n", b'consolidated financial statements for further information regarding the\n', b'individual components of the 1996 special charge and details of the 1997\n', b"activity in the Company's restructuring accrual.\n", b'\n', b'\n', b'YEAR ENDED DECEMBER 29, 1996 COMPARED TO THE YEAR ENDED DECEMBER 31, 1995\n', b'\n', b'\n', b"     The Company's operating results for 1996 include the effects of a pre-tax\n", b'special charge of $337.6 million recorded in conjunction with the\n', b'implementation of its restructuring and growth plan announced in November 1996.\n', b'Approximately 20% of the charge was for cash items primarily for severance\n', b'costs and lease and other facility exit costs. The special charge to earnings\n', b'in 1996 is included in the following categories on the consolidated statement\n', b'of operations (in millions):\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'<TABLE>\n', b'<CAPTION>\n', b'                                                         PRE-TAX DOLLAR        AFTER-TAX\n', b'                                                             AMOUNT         PER SHARE AMOUNT\n', b'                                                        ----------------   -----------------\n', b'<S>                                                     <C>                <C>\n', b'Restructuring, impairment and other costs ...........       $  154.9            $ (1.21)\n', b'Cost of sales .......................................           92.3              (0.72)\n', b'Selling, general and administrative .................           42.5              (0.33)\n', b'Estimated loss from discontinued operations .........           47.9              (0.39)\n', b'                                                            --------            -------\n', b'Total ...............................................       $  337.6            $ (2.65)\n', b'                                                            ========            =======\n', b'</TABLE>\n', b'\n', b'     Net sales from continuing operations of $984.2 million for 1996 represents\n', b'a decrease of $32.7 million, or 3.2%, from 1995. The Company experienced a loss\n', b'from continuing operations of $196.7 million or $2.37 per share for 1996 versus\n', b'earnings from continuing operations of $37.6 million or $.45 per share\n', b'(diluted) in 1995 primarily as a result of the restructuring activities\n', b'discussed above. The net loss for 1996 was $228.3 million, or $2.75 per share,\n', b'compared to net earnings of $50.5 million, or $0.61 per share (diluted), for\n', b'1995. Excluding the impact of special charge items for 1996, earnings from\n', b'continuing operations before income taxes decreased from $60.6 million in 1995\n', b'to a loss of $12.9 million in 1996.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Domestic sales represented approximately 80% of total sales of the Company\n', b'in 1996 and decreased $28.5 million or 3.4% from 1995. This sales decline was\n', b'driven by lower sales of outdoor cooking products, which declined 7.3% and\n', b'lower sales of bedding products which declined 9.0% from 1995, primarily as\n', b'result of lower decorative bedding sales (divested in December 1996). Domestic\n', b'sales of appliance products were flat with sales increases from new products\n', b'such as vegetable steamers and toaster ovens being offset by reduced pricing on\n', b'breadmakers. Sales of other product categories such as health and personal care\n', b'products and time and temperature products (divested in March 1997) were either\n', b'flat or declined slightly from 1995 levels.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     International sales decreased $4.2 million or 2.2% from 1995 primarily as\n', b'a result of lower sales in Latin America due to political and/or economic\n', b'instability in several countries such as Ecuador, Peru, Columbia and Venezuela\n', b'(which suffered a bolivar devaluation in April 1996), a sales decline of 11.2%\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'                                       16\n', b'<PAGE>\n', b'\n', b"in Canada as a result of the bankruptcy filing of the Company's then largest\n", b'Canadian customer offset by a 55.0% increase in sales in Mexico as a result of\n', b'a more stable economic environment in 1996.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b"     The Company's gross margin percentage, excluding the impact of special\n", b'charges, was 17.9% of sales in 1996, down from 20.4% in 1995, primarily from\n', b'the underabsorption of higher manufacturing costs and excess manufacturing\n', b"capacity that has been realigned for 1997 and beyond by the Company's\n", b'restructuring and growth plan cost reduction initiatives.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Selling, general and administrative ("SG&A") expenses, excluding the\n', b'impact of special charges described above, were 17.6% of sales in 1996\n', b'primarily as a result of an inflated cost structure that has been realigned for\n', b'1997 and beyond. In addition, a $12.0 million fourth quarter 1996 media\n', b'advertising campaign and one-time expenditures for market research, new\n', b'packaging, and other growth plan initiatives resulted in higher than normal\n', b'SG&A spending in 1996. Also included in 1996 SG&A costs were $7.7 million of\n', b'compensation expense resulting from restricted stock awards made in connection\n', b'with the employment of a new senior management team.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Interest expense for 1996 increased from $9.4 million in 1995 to $13.6\n', b'million as a result of increased indebtedness of the Company for working\n', b'capital requirements and non-recurring capitalized interest in 1995 related to\n', b'the construction of the Hattiesburg manufacturing and distribution center.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The effective income tax rate for 1996 decreased 3 percentage points from\n', b'1995 to 35.0% as a result of certain foreign and state operating losses for\n', b'which no tax benefits were recorded and the non-deductibility of compensation\n', b'expense related to restricted stock awards.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b"     The Company's discontinued furniture operations had revenues of $227.5\n", b'million in 1996, up 22.6% from $185.6 million in 1995. This revenue growth was\n', b'the result of the acquisition of the Samsonite/registered trademark/ furniture\n', b'business in November 1995. Excluding the impact of this acquisition, furniture\n', b'business sales declined 2.1%. Earnings from the discontinued furniture\n', b'operations, net of taxes, declined from $12.9 million in 1995 to $.8 million in\n', b'1996 primarily as a result of lower gross margins from reduced pricing,\n', b'underabsorption of higher manufacturing costs and higher raw material costs. In\n', b'addition, SG&A costs increased due to the inclusion of the Samsonite/registered\n', b'trademark/ furniture business, higher distribution and warehousing costs,\n', b'particularly with resin furniture products and higher bad debt expenses.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'FOREIGN OPERATIONS\n', b'\n', b'\n', b"     During 1997 approximately 90% of the Company's business was conducted in\n", b'U.S. dollars (including both domestic sales, U.S. dollar denominated export\n', b'sales primarily to certain Latin American markets, Asian sales and the majority\n', b"of European sales). The Company's exposure to market risk from changes in\n", b"foreign currency and interest rates is generally insignificant. The Company's\n", b'non-U.S. dollar denominated sales are made principally by subsidiaries in\n', b'Mexico, Venezuela and Canada. Venezuela is considered a hyperinflationary\n', b'economy for accounting purposes for 1995, 1996 and 1997 and Mexico reverted to\n', b'hyperinflationary status for accounting purposes in 1997; therefore, translation\n', b'adjustments related to Venezuelan and Mexican net monetary assets are included\n', b'as a component of net earnings. Such translation adjustments were not material\n', b'to 1995, 1996 and 1997 operating results.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     On a limited basis, the Company selectively uses derivatives (foreign\n', b'exchange option and forward contracts) to manage foreign exchange exposures\n', b'that arise in the normal course of business. No derivative contracts are\n', b'entered into for trading or speculative purposes. The use of derivatives did\n', b"not have a material impact on the Company's financial results in 1995, 1996 and\n", b"1997. See Note 4 to the Company's consolidated financial statements.\n", b'\n', b'\n', b'LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     As of December 28, 1997, the Company had cash and cash equivalents of\n', b'$52.4 million and total debt of $195.2 million. This decrease is primarily\n', b'attributable to an increase in earnings before non-cash charges in 1997 and the\n', b"utilization of tax benefits generated from the implementation of the Company's\n", b'restructuring plan, offset by higher accounts receivable due to increased sales\n', b'in 1997 and certain seasonal dating terms, increased inventory levels in 1997\n', b"necessary to support continued anticipated sales growth and the Company's\n", b'initiatives to improve customer service levels and 1997 cash expenditures\n', b'required to implement the restructuring plan. Capital spending\n', b'in 1996 was $75.3 million (including $14.5 million related to the discontinued\n', b'furniture operations) and was primarily attributable to new product\n', b'development, cost reduction initiatives and a $5.0 million warehouse expansion\n', b'financed with a capital lease. OPERATIONS AND SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'ORGANIZATION\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Sunbeam Corporation ("Sunbeam" or the "Company") is a leading manufacturer\n', b'and marketer of branded consumer products. The Sunbeam/registered trademark/\n', b'and Oster/registered trademark/ brands have been household names for\n', b'generations, and the Company is a market share leader in many of its product\n', b'categories.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The Company markets its products through virtually every category of\n', b'retailer including mass merchandisers, catalog showrooms, warehouse clubs,\n', b'department stores, catalogs, television shopping channels, Company-owned outlet\n', b'stores, hardware stores, home centers, drug and grocery stores, pet supply\n', b'retailers, as well as independent distributors and the military. The Company\n', b'also sells its products to commercial end users such as hotels and other\n', b'institutions.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Approximately 79% of total Company sales are generated in the United\n', b'States. The remaining sales are generated primarily in Latin America, Mexico,\n', b'Canada, Europe and Asia.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'PRINCIPLES OF CONSOLIDATION\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company\n', b'and all majority-owned subsidiaries that it controls. All material intercompany\n', b'balances and transactions have been eliminated.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'PRESENTATION OF FISCAL PERIODS\n', b'\n', b'\n', b"     The Company's fiscal year ends on the Sunday nearest December 31. Fiscal\n", b'years 1997, 1996 and 1995 ended on December 28, 1997, December 29, 1996, and\n', b'December 31, 1995 respectively, which encompassed 52-week periods.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'USE OF ESTIMATES\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The preparation of the consolidated financial statements in conformity\n', b'with generally accepted accounting principles requires management to make\n', b'estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the consolidated\n', b'financial statements and accompanying notes. Actual results could differ from\n', b'those estimates. Significant accounting estimates include the establishment of\n', b'the allowance for doubtful accounts, reserves for product warranty, product\n', b'liability, excess and obsolete inventory, litigation and environmental\n', b'exposures.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'CONCENTRATIONS OF CREDIT RISK\n', b'\n', b'\n', b"     Substantially all of the Company's trade receivables are due from\n", b'retailers and distributors located throughout the United States, Latin America\n', b"and Canada. Approximately 36% of the Company's sales in 1997 were to its five\n", b'largest customers. The Company establishes its credit policies based on an\n', b"ongoing evaluation of its customers' creditworthiness and competitive market\n", b'conditions and establishes its allowance for doubtful accounts based on an\n', b'assessment of exposures to credit losses at each balance sheet date. The\n', b'Company believes its allowance for doubtful accounts is sufficient based on the\n', b'credit exposures outstanding at December 28, 1997. However, certain retailers\n', b'filed for bankruptcy protection in the last several years and it is possible\n', b'that additional credit losses could be incurred if the trends of retail\n', b'consolidation continue.\n', b'\n', b'                                      F-7\n', b'<PAGE>\n', b'\n', b'                     SUNBEAM CORPORATION AND SUBSIDIARIES\n', b'\n', b'            NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS--(CONTINUED)\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'1. OPERATIONS AND SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES--(CONTINUED)\n', b'\n', b'INVENTORIES\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market with cost being\n', b'determined principally by the first-in, first-out method.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'PROPERTY, PLANT AND EQUIPMENT\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Property, plant and equipment is stated at cost. The Company provides for\n', b'depreciation using primarily the straight-line method in amounts that allocate\n', b'the cost of property, plant and equipment over the following useful lives:\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'<TABLE>\n', b'<S>                                                 <C>\n', b'       Buildings and improvements ...............   20 to 40 years\n', b'       Machinery, equipment and tooling .........    3 to 15 years\n', b'       Furniture and fixtures ...................    3 to 10 years\n', b'</TABLE>\n', b'\n', b'     Leasehold improvements are amortized on a straight-line basis over the\n', b'shorter of its estimated useful life or the term of the lease.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'LONG-LIVED ASSETS\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The Company accounts for long-lived assets pursuant to Statement of\n', b'Financial Accounting Standards ("SFAS") No. 121, ACCOUNTING FOR THE IMPAIRMENT\n', b'OF LONG-LIVED ASSETS AND FOR LONG-LIVED ASSETS TO BE DISPOSED OF. See Notes 8\n', b'and 9 for a discussion of asset impairment charges in 1996.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'CAPITALIZED INTEREST\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Interest costs for the construction of certain long-term assets are\n', b"capitalized and amortized over the related assets' estimated useful lives.\n", b'Total interest costs during 1997 and 1996 amounted to $12.3 million and $14.0\n', b'million respectively, of which $.9 million and $.4 million respectively, was\n', b'capitalized into the construction cost of the long-term assets.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'AMORTIZATION PERIODS\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Trademarks and trade names are being amortized on a straight-line basis\n', b'over 40 years.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'REVENUE RECOGNITION\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The Company recognizes revenues from product sales principally at the time\n', b'of shipment to customers. In limited circumstances, at the customers request\n', b'the Company may sell seasonal product on a bill and hold basis provided that\n', b'the goods are completed, packaged and ready for shipment, such goods are\n', b'segregated and the risks of ownership and legal title have passed to the\n', b'customer. The amount of such bill and hold sales at December 29, 1997 was\n', b'approximately 3% of consolidated revenues.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Net sales is comprised of gross sales less provisions for expected\n', b'customer returns, discounts, promotional allowances and cooperative\n', b'advertising.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'WARRANTY COSTS\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The Company provides for warranty costs in amounts it estimates will be\n', b'needed to cover future warranty obligations for products sold during the year.\n', b'Estimates of warranty costs are periodically reviewed and adjusted, when\n', b'necessary, to consider actual experience.\n', b'\n', b'                                      F-8\n', b'<PAGE>\n', b'\n', b'                     SUNBEAM CORPORATION AND SUBSIDIARIES\n', b'\n', b'            NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS--(CONTINUED)\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'1. OPERATIONS AND SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES--(CONTINUED)\n', b'\n', b'ADVERTISING COSTS\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Media advertising costs included in "Selling, General and Administrative\n', b'Expense," are expensed as incurred. Co-operative advertising costs are expensed\n', b'ratably over the year in relation to revenues.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'FOREIGN CURRENCY TRANSLATION\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The assets and liabilities of subsidiaries, other than those operating in\n', b'highly inflationary environments, are translated into U.S. dollars at year-end\n', b'exchange rates, with resulting translation gains and losses accumulated in a\n', b"separate component of shareholders' equity. Income and expense items are\n", b'converted into U.S. dollars at average rates of exchange prevailing during the\n', b'year.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     For subsidiaries operating in highly inflationary environments, (Venezuela\n', b'and Mexico) inventories and property, plant and equipment are translated at the\n', b'rate of exchange on the date the assets were acquired, while other assets and\n', b'liabilities are translated at year-end exchange rates. Translation adjustments\n', b'for those operations are included in "Other (income) expense, net" on the\n', b'Accompanying Consolidated Statements of Operations.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'STOCK-BASED COMPENSATION PLANS\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     SFAS No. 123, ACCOUNTING FOR STOCK-BASED COMPENSATION allows either\n', b'adoption of a fair value method for accounting for stock-based compensation\n', b'plans or continuation of accounting under Accounting Principles Board ("APB")\n', b'Opinion No.  25, ACCOUNTING FOR STOCK ISSUED TO EMPLOYEES, and related\n', b'interpretations with supplemental disclosures.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The Company has chosen to account for its stock options using the\n', b'intrinsic value based method prescribed in APB Opinion No. 25 and, accordingly,\n', b'does not recognize compensation expense for stock option grants made at an\n', b'exercise price equal to or in excess of the fair market value of the stock at\n', b'the date of grant. Pro forma net income and earnings per share amounts as if\n', b'the fair value method had been adopted are presented in Note 5 herein. SFAS No.\n', b"123 does not impact the Company's results of operations, financial position or\n", b'cash flows.\n', b'\n', b'                                      F-9\n', b'<PAGE>\n', b'\n', b'                     SUNBEAM CORPORATION AND SUBSIDIARIES\n', b'\n', b'            NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS--(CONTINUED)\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'1. OPERATIONS AND SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES--(CONTINUED)\n', b'\n', b'EARNINGS PER SHARE OF COMMON STOCK\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     In 1997, the Company adopted SFAS No. 128, EARNINGS PER SHARE. Basic\n', b'earnings per common share calculations are determined by dividing earnings\n', b'available to common shareholders by the weighted average number of shares of\n', b'common stock. Diluted earnings per share are determined by dividing earnings\n', b'available to common shareholders by the weighted average number of shares of\n', b'common stock and dilutive common stock equivalents outstanding (all related to\n', b'outstanding stock options and restricted stock discussed in Note 5). The\n', b"Company's reported primary earnings per share for 1995 has been restated to\n", b'comply with the requirements of SFAS No. 128. SFAS No. 128 had no impact on the\n', b"Company's reported loss per share for 1996 and no impact on the diluted\n", b'earnings per share reported in 1995. The effect of this accounting change on\n', b'previously reported earnings per share (EPS) for 1995 was as follows:\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'<TABLE>\n', b'<S>                                                   <C>\n', b'      Earnings per share from continuing operations\n', b'       Primary EPS as reported ....................    $  0.45\n', b'       Effect of SFAS No. 128 .....................       0.01\n', b'       Basic EPS as restated ......................       0.46\n', b'      Earnings per share\n', b'       Primary EPS as reported ....................    $  0.61\n', b'       Effect of SFAS No. 128 .....................       0.01\n', b'       Basic EPS as restated ......................       0.62\n', b'</TABLE>\n', b'\n', b'RECLASSIFICATION\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Certain prior year amounts have been reclassified to conform with the 1997\n', b'presentation.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'NEW ACCOUNTING STANDARDS\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     In June 1997, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ("FASB") issued\n', b'SFAS No. 130, REPORTING COMPREHENSIVE INCOME. SFAS No. 130 establishes\n', b'standards for reporting and display of comprehensive income and its components\n', b'in the financial statements. SFAS No. 130 is effective for fiscal years\n', b'beginning after December 15, 1997. Reclassification of financial statements for\n', b'earlier periods provided for comparative purposes is required. The Company is\n', b'in the process of determining its preferred format. The adoption of SFAS No.\n', b"130 will have no impact on the Company's consolidated results of operations,\n", b'financial position or cash flows.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     In June 1997, the FASB issued SFAS No. 131, DISCLOSURES ABOUT SEGMENTS OF\n', b'AN ENTERPRISE AND RELATED INFORMATION. SFAS No. 131 establishes standards for\n', b'the way that public business enterprises report information about operating\n', b'segments in annual financial statements and requires that those enterprises\n', b'report selected information about operating segments in interim financial\n', b'reports issued to shareholders. It also establishes standards for related\n', b'disclosures about products and services, geographic areas, and major customers.\n', b'SFAS No. 131 is effective for financial statements for fiscal years beginning\n', b'after December 15, 1997. Financial statement disclosures for prior periods are\n', b'required to be restated. The Company is in the process of evaluating the\n', b'disclosure requirements. The adoption of SFAS No. 131 will have no impact on\n', b'consolidated results of operations, financial position or cash flow.\n', b'\n', b'                                      F-10\n', b'<PAGE>\n', b'\n', b'                     SUNBEAM CORPORATION AND SUBSIDIARIES\n', b'\n', b'            NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS--(CONTINUED)\n', b'\n', b"2. SHAREHOLDERS' EQUITY\n", b'\n', b'\n', b'     The Company has 200,000,000 shares of $.01 par value common stock\n', b'authorized. At December 28, 1997 there were 9,404,068 shares of common stock\n', b'reserved for issuance upon the exercise of outstanding stock options.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     In June 1995, the Company retired 7,376,395 shares of common stock held in\n', b'treasury, and such shares were returned to the status of authorized but\n', b'unissued shares. As a result, $103.7 million assigned to treasury stock has\n', b'been eliminated with a corresponding decrease to common stock, paid-in capital\n', b'and retained earnings. In 1995, the Company repurchased 905,600 shares of its\n', b'common stock at a total cost of $13.1 million.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     In July 1996, the Company sold 321,786 shares of common stock for total\n', b'proceeds of approximately $4.4 million, and granted 1,100,000 shares of\n', b'restricted stock in connection with the employment of a new Chairman and Chief\n', b'Executive Officer and certain other officers of the Company. Compensation\n', b'expense attributable to the restricted stock awards is being amortized to\n', b'expense beginning in 1996 over the periods in which the restrictions lapse\n', b'(which in the case of 333,333 shares, was immediately upon the date of grant,\n', b'in the case of 666,667 shares, is equally over two years from the date of grant\n', b'and in the case of the remaining restricted shares, is equally over three years\n', b'from the dates of grant).\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     On February 20, 1998 the Company entered into new three-year employment\n', b'agreements with its Chairman and Chief Executive Officer and two other senior\n', b'officers of the Company. CREDIT FACILITIES AND LONG-TERM DEBT\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     In 1994, the Mississippi Business Finance Corporation ("MBFC") issued $75\n', b'million of 7.85% Industrial Development Revenue Notes (the "Notes") maturing\n', b'serially in eleven equal annual installments beginning June 1999 to certain\n', b'institutional investors through a private placement. The MBFC loaned the\n', b'proceeds of the Notes to a subsidiary of the Company under a non-recourse loan\n', b'agreement (the "Hattiesburg Loan") restricting the use of such funds to the\n', b'acquisition, design, construction and equipping of the Hattiesburg, Mississippi\n', b'manufacturing and distribution center. The Notes are guaranteed by the Company\n', b'and the Hattiesburg Loan is secured by the Hattiesburg facility.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     In September 1996 (as subsequently amended), the Company entered into a\n', b'$500 million syndicated unsecured five year revolving credit facility (the\n', b'"Credit Agreement") which replaced a previous credit facility of $500 million.\n', b'In July 1997, the Company reduced the amount of available borrowings under the\n', b'facility to $250 million. Under the Credit Agreement, the Company can borrow\n', b'under a competitive bid option, or at a spread above LIBOR (currently .5%) or\n', b'at a bank base rate. In addition, the Company pays an annual facility fee\n', b'(currently .25%). The Credit Agreement contains certain financial covenants.\n', b'\n', b'                                      F-12\n', b'<PAGE>\n', b'\n', b'                     SUNBEAM CORPORATION AND SUBSIDIARIES\n', b'\n', b'            NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS--(CONTINUED)\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'3. CREDIT FACILITIES AND LONG-TERM DEBT--(CONTINUED)\n', b'\n', b'     During 1997, the Company repaid $12.2 million of long-term borrowings\n', b'related to the divested furntiture operations and other assets sold.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     The aggregate annual principal payments on long-term debt, excluding\n', b'amounts outstanding under the Credit Agreement, due in each of the years\n', b'1998-2002, are $.7 million, $7.5 million, $7.6 million, $7.6 million and $7.7\n', b'million, respectively.\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'     Long-term debt at the end of each fiscal year consists of the following\n', b'(in thousands):\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'\n', b'<TABLE>\n', b'<CAPTION>\n', b'                                                                                1997          1996\n', b'                                                                            -----------   -----------\n', b'<S>                                                                         <C>           <C>\n',
